Ninth: One should observe in the Friday prayer leader what we have mentioned in others. When he hears the Imam's recitation, he should not recite except the Opening (Al-Fatihah). When he finishes the Friday prayer, he should read 'Praise be to Allah' seven times before speaking, and 'Say: He is Allah, the One' (Qul Huwa Allahu Ahad) and the two seeking refuge surahs (Al-Mu'awwidhatayn) seven times each. Some of the predecessors (Salaf) narrated: Whoever does this is protected from one Friday to the next and it becomes a shield for him from Satan. It is recommended to say after the Friday prayer: O Allah, O Rich (Al-Ghani), O Praiseworthy (Al-Hamid), O Originator (Al-Mubdi'), O Restorer (Al-Mu'id), O Merciful (Al-Rahim), O Loving (Al-Wadud), enrich me with Your lawful provision over Your unlawful, and with Your bounty over whoever besides You. It is said: Whoever persists in this supplication, Allah the Exalted enriches him from His creation and provides for him from where he does not expect. Then he prays after the Friday prayer six units of prayer.

Glory be to the Possessor of might and generosity. Glory be to the Possessor of abundance. I ask You by the bonds of might from Your Throne (Arsh) and the utmost of mercy from Your Book, and by Your Greatest Name (Ism al-A'zam) and Your Highest Majesty (Jadd al-A'la) and Your perfect, comprehensive words that no righteous or wicked one surpasses, that You send blessings upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad.' The Seventh: The Prayer of Seeking Guidance (Salat al-Istikhara). For whoever intends a matter and does not know its outcome, nor knows whether the good lies in leaving it or in proceeding with it, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) has commanded him to pray two units (rak'atayn), reciting in the first unit the Opening of the Book (Surah al-Fatiha) and 'Say, O you disbelievers' (Surah al-Kafirun), and in the second unit the Opening (al-Fatiha) and 'Say: He is Allah, the One (Ahad)' (Surah al-Ikhlas). Then, when he finishes, he supplicates and says: 'O Allah, I seek Your guidance through Your knowledge, and I seek ability through Your power, and I ask You from Your immense bounty, for You have power and I have no power, and You know and I do not know, and You are the Knower of the unseen. O Allah, if You know that this matter is good for me in my religion, my worldly life, and the outcome of my affair, its immediate and its deferred, then decree it for me, bless me in it, and then make it easy for me. And if You know that this matter is evil for me in my religion, my worldly life, and the outcome of my affair, its immediate and its deferred, then turn me away from it and turn it away from me, and decree for me the good wherever it may be, for You have power over all things.' [290] Narrated by Jabir ibn Abdullah who said: 'The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) used to teach us the seeking of guidance in all matters as he would teach us a chapter from the Quran.' And he (peace be upon him) said: 'When one of you intends a matter, let him pray two units, then let him name the matter and supplicate with what we have mentioned.'

The Quran is nothing except it is guidance and light and a making-known from Allah the Exalted to His creation, so at times He makes Himself known to them through sanctification (Taqdis) when He says: "Say: He is Allah, the One, Allah, the Eternal Refuge. He neither begets nor is born, nor is there to Him any equivalent (Kufuwan) one." And at times He makes Himself known to them through attributes of His majesty when He says: "The Sovereign, the Holy, the Peace, the Faithful, the Guardian, the Exalted in Might, the Compeller, the Superior." And at times He makes Himself known to them in His actions that are feared and hoped for, and He recites to them His way (Sunnah) with His enemies and with His prophets when He says: "Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with 'Aad - Iram of the pillars? Have you not considered how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant?" And the Quran does not exceed these three divisions, which are: guidance to knowledge of the essence (Dhat) of Allah and His sanctification (Taqdis), or knowledge of His attributes and His names, or knowledge of His actions and His way (Sunnah) with His servants. And since Surah Al-Ikhlas contained one of these three divisions, which is sanctification (Taqdis), the Messenger of Allah ï·º equated it with a third of the Quran, saying: "Whoever recites Surah Al-Ikhlas has recited a third of the Quran" because the utmost sanctification (Taqdis) is to be one in three matters: there is not originating from Him one who is His counterpart and likeness, and His statement "He neither begets" indicates this; and there is not originating from one who is His counterpart and likeness, and His statement "nor is born" indicates this; and there is not in His rank, even if not being an origin for Him nor a branch, one who is His like, and His statement indicates this: "nor is there to Him any equivalent (Kufuwan) one." And all of that is gathered by His statement the Exalted: "Say: He is Allah, the One" and its entirety is the detailing of the saying "There is no god but Allah." These are the secrets of the Quran, and examples of these secrets in the Quran do not end, "and not a moist thing nor a dry thing except in a clear Book."
